display_asset.caption: An image from the teaser trailer for “Doctor Strange.”

summaries.body: The trailer for "Doctor Strange" is something for Marvel fans to ponder, with Benedict Cumberbatch as a surgeon with impaired hands, a bald and wizened Tilda Swinton and a New York City that unfolds like an Escher drawing.

display_asset.caption: Inky the octopus at National Aquarium of New Zealand in Napier.

summaries.body: After squeezing through a small gap in his enclosure at the National Aquarium of New Zealand, an octopus named Inky scampered across the floor and shinnied down a drainpipe to the freedom of Hawke's Bay.

display_asset.caption: The Kindle Oasis. Amazon says its Kindle business is still growing, despite competition from other devices.

summaries.body: The new $289 Kindle Oasis e-reader from Amazon has an asymmetrical shape meant to mimic a book, and promises "months and months" of battery life.

display_asset.caption: Wakko, Yakko and their sister, Dot, of “Animaniacs.”

summaries.body: "Animaniacs," a beloved after-school cartoon for children of the '90s, is now on Netflix. It's also going on tour with live performances of many of the show’s songs, including an updated version of "Yakko's World."

display_asset.caption: Alice Paul, second from left, the founder of the National Women’s Party, sewed a 36th star on the flag that flew outside the party’s headquarters in Washington after the 19th Amendment was ratified in 1920. The star represented Tennessee, whose ratification completed the number of states needed to approve the amendment, which gave women the right to vote.

summaries.body: President Obama has designated the Sewall-Belmont House on Capitol Hill as a national monument for women's equality, calling it a symbol of the American fight for civil rights.

display_asset.caption: Two employees of the Drug Enforcement Administration are scheduled to go on trial next month on charges that they lied about ownership in a strip club, shown last May, in New Jersey.
display_asset.credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times

summaries.body: Two D.E.A. employees are trying to bar a lap-dance video from evidence at their trial on charges that during background checks they lied about owning a New Jersey strip club.

display_asset.caption: Macedonians clashed with the police during a protest against President Gjorge Ivanov’s decision to halt a wiretapping inquiry, in Skopje, Macedonia, on Tuesday.

summaries.body: Protesters gathered in Macedonia after the president halted an investigation into widespread corruption in government, including surveillance of up to 20,000 people.

display_asset.caption: Sean Parker is donating $250 million to start the Parker Institute for Cancer Immunotherapy, an effort that he said represented a new “blueprint for biomedical research funding.”

summaries.body: Sean Parker, the Napster and Facebook pioneer, is donating $250 million for an institute developing ways to unleash patients’ own immune systems to fight cancer.
Arthur Anderson, who performed on radio as a teenager with Orson Welles’s Mercury Theater and was the voice of Lucky Charms cereal’s leprechaun, has died at 93.
A French website that recently posted a recipe for one-pot pasta carbonara set off outrage among Italians over some of the suggested substitutions.

display_asset.caption: Passengers checking in at a Brussels airport in Zaventem last week. Americans and Canadians can generally travel to Europe without a visa, but that may change.

summaries.body: The European Union has delayed until summer a decision on whether to require United States and Canadian citizens to obtain visas to travel to Europe.

display_asset.caption: John Whittingdale in 2015.

summaries.body: John Whittingdale, the British minister of culture, said that he used to date a woman in the sex industry and that tabloids had known about it, but he denied that it had affected his regulation of the news media.

display_asset.caption: Oscar Murillo

summaries.body: When the Colombian artist Oscar Murillo flushed his British passport down an airplane toilet, he had not intended to stage a protest. But the action became one, he said.
Women searching for tech jobs are often setting their salary expectations lower than their male counterparts are, according to Hired, a job marketplace for the industry.
Happy 100th birthday, Beverly Cleary. The Times Book Review looks back at the children's writer and her work, including "Ramona Quimby" and "Henry Huggins."

display_asset.caption: The Pepsi-Cola sign, in what is now Gantry Plaza State Park in Long Island City, Queens, faces the East River and Manhattan.
display_asset.credit: Benjamin Norman for The New York Times

summaries.body: After a nearly 30-year wait, the iconic Pepsi-Cola sign on the waterfront of Long Island City, Queens, has gained official landmark status.

display_asset.caption: A crowd organized by the Student Non-Violent Coordinating Committee sings “We Shall Overcome” in Farmville, Va., in 1966, after a speech by Stokely Carmichael.

summaries.body: The copyright for "We Shall Overcome" may be overcome one day. A nonprofit group is seeking to have the famous protest song declared in the public domain.

display_asset.caption: Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, discussing changes to the Messenger platform at the company’s annual F8 developer conference in San Francisco.

summaries.body: Facebook is hailing the rise of the bots. It is opening up its messaging app so that any outside company can create a bot capable of chatting with real people.

display_asset.caption: Led Zeppelin performed at Madison Square Garden in 1975.
display_asset.credit: Larry C. Morris/The New York Times

summaries.body: A Los Angeles judge ruled that it will be up to jurors next month to decide whether Led Zeppelin's song “Stairway to Heaven” stole elements of “Taurus,” a track by Spirit.

display_asset.caption: The control room at Al Jazeera America, which went on the air in August 2013. The station shuts down Tuesday night.

summaries.body: Al Jazeera America will air its final broadcast on Tuesday, closing at midnight. Here's a look back at the television network over its turbulent three years.

display_asset.caption: “Campbell’s Soup Cans” paintings by Andy Warhol were displayed at the Museum of Modern Art in New York last year. The stolen prints were based on these paintings.
display_asset.credit: Emon Hassan for The New York Times

summaries.body: Seven screen prints of Andy Warhol’s Campbell’s Soup cans were snatched from an art museum in Springfield, Mo. The F.B.I. has offered a $25,000 reward.

display_asset.caption: Ali al-Amin with the two children. The children were abducted last week by three “armed persons.” Their mother and eight others face charges.

summaries.body: An Australian woman and eight other people, including four journalists, are facing criminal charges in Lebanon after she tried to take her two children from her Lebanese ex-husband.

display_asset.caption: James Taylor is retiring after it was discovered he has a heart condition.

summaries.body: The English cricket star James Taylor is retiring at age 26 after being diagnosed with a serious heart condition.

display_asset.caption: Lt. Cmdr. Edward C. Lin of the United States Navy, a native of Taiwan, speaking at a naturalization ceremony in Honolulu in 2008.
display_asset.credit: Sarah Murphy/US NAVY, via Associated Press

summaries.body: Taiwan's military said it had not received secrets from an American naval officer under investigation on suspicion of providing information to Taiwan or China.

display_asset.caption: Keegan-Michael Key, left, and Jeff Probst on MadTV in 2008.

summaries.body: “MadTV” is returning for eight episodes on the CW network. The sketch comedy series ran for 14 years and started the careers of the comedy duo Key and Peele, among others.

display_asset.caption: A poster in the Indian state of Kerala shows three of the more than 100 victims of the explosion at Puttingal temple.

summaries.body: Thirteen people have been arrested in connection with the explosions that killed more than 100 during a fireworks display at a temple in southern India over the weekend.

display_asset.caption: Opponents of North Carolina’s new law on gay and transgender rights protested outside the State Capitol in Raleigh on Monday.
display_asset.credit: Ray Whitehouse for The New York Times

summaries.body: North Carolina's new law on gay and transgender rights has deepened political rifts in a state that has long been considered one of the South's most moderate.
The Belgian authorities have charged two more men with offenses related to the Brussels bombings.
The butlers, florists and chefs who are a permanent part of the White House’s staff are following the election closely. Our next president is their new boss.

display_asset.caption: The Turkish Embassy has requested that Germany prosecute the television comic and satirist Jan Böhmermann under a little-known law on insulting foreign leaders.
display_asset.credit: Jörg Carstensen/Deutsche Presse-Agentur, via Associated Press

summaries.body: A German comedian's takedown of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey may have run afoul of a little-known German law on insulting foreign leaders.
